clinical_study.brief_title: Cardiovascular Responses to Exercise in People Living With HIV/AIDS: Effects of Exercise Training
clinical_study.official_title: Autonomic and Hemodynamic Responses to Muscular Ergoreflex Activation in People Living With HIV/AIDS: Effects of Exercise Training.

lead_sponsor.agency: Instituto Nacional de Cardiologia de Laranjeiras

clinical_study.source: Instituto Nacional de Cardiologia de Laranjeiras

brief_summary.textblock: Background: People living with HIV (PLHIV) present impaired muscle metaboreflex, which may lead to exercise intolerance and increased cardiovascular risk. This study will aim to investigate the effects of exercise training on autonomic and hemodynamic responses to muscle ergoreflex activation in PLHIV. Methods: This is a randomized controlled clinical trial, in which PLHIV without regular physical exercise will be randomly assigned at a ratio of 1:1 into an intervention or a control group. The intervention group will perform an exercise training program (aerobic, strength and flexibility exercises) for 12 weeks (60-min session performed 3 times/wk with moderate intensity) and the control group will remain inactive. A reference group composed of inactive HIV-uninfected group will be included. The primary outcomes will be blood pressure and autonomic markers in response to the Stroop Color-Word Test and the activation of muscle ergoreflex, by means of the post-exercise circulatory arrest (PECA), being the latter performed with and without the application of a capsaicin-based analgesic balm in the exercised limb. Secondary outcomes will be peripheral vascular resistance, cardiac output, heart rate and blood lactate. The active and inactive PLHIV groups will be evaluated at baseline and after the intervention, while the reference group only at baseline.

detailed_description.textblock: HIV-infection is associated to a reduced maximal cardiac output and blunted pressor reflex response to static handgrip exercise, which are suggestive of impaired ergoreflex activation. An abnormal ergoreflex activation may lead to exercise intolerance and increases in cardiovascular risk. Despite the importance of therapeutic strategies in reducing the cardiovascular risk among patients living with HIV, exercise-related effects on ergoreflex sensitivity in these population have not been previously investigated.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: HIV+active group will perform exercise training, while HIV+inactive and HIV- groups will not undergo intervention.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline Blood Pressure at 3 months
primary_outcome.description: Blood pressure will be assessed by photoplethysmography.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline Heart Rate at 3 months
secondary_outcome.description: Heart rate will be evaluated beat-to-beat by means of a heart rate monitor.

intervention.description: Exercise training performed during 12 weeks, 3 sessions per week of 60 minutes of strength and aerobic exercises.
